Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: Community Software for Extreme-Scale Computing in Earthquake System Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Software Environment for Integrated Seismic Modeling (SEISM) Project of the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC) will develop advanced earthquake simulation software capable of using high-performance computing to produce new information about earthquakes and the hazards they present. SCEC's SEISM project is developing an integrated, sustainable community software framework for earthquake system science to serve diverse communities of earthquake scientists and engineers, computer scientists, and at-risk stakeholders. The SEISM project is a collaboration among several diverse user communities with shared interests in reducing seismic risk and enhancing seismic resilience. SCEC SEISM researchers are addressing scientific problems that limit the accuracy and scale in current numerical representations of earthquake processes. SEISM computational improvements in seismic hazard calculations will benefit earthquake system science worldwide. The SCEC SEISM project will educate a diverse STEM workforce from the undergraduate to early-career level, and it will cross-train scientists and engineers in a challenging high-performance environment. As one application of SEISM, the researchers will develop new simulations for the Great California ShakeOut, which is engaging millions of people in earthquake preparedness exercises.

Earthquake simulations at the spatiotemporal scales required for probabilistic seismic hazard analysis present some of the toughest computational challenges in geoscience, requiring extreme-scale computing. The Southern California Earthquake Center is creating a Software Environment for Integrated Seismic Modeling (SEISM) that will provide the extreme-scale simulation capability needed to transform probabilistic seismic hazard analysis into a physics-based science. This project will advance SEISM through a user-driven research and development agenda that will push validated SEISM capabilities to higher seismic frequencies and towards extreme-scale computing. It will develop an integrated, sustainable community software framework for earthquake system science to serve diverse communities of earthquake scientists and engineers, computer scientists and at-risk stakeholders. A new SEISM-T framework will support both in-situ and post-hoc data processing to make efficient use of available heterogeneous architectures. The main goal of the project is to increase the 4D outer-scale/inner-scale ratio of simulations at constant time-to-solution by two orders of magnitude above current capabilities. The software development plan will use an agile process of test-driven development, continuous software integration, automated acceptance test suites for each application, frequent software releases, and attention to user feedback. The researchers will take advantage of the SCEC Implementation Interface to develop a dialog among user communities regarding the application of SEISM to the reduction of seismic risk and enhancement of seismic resilience. This research will address fundamental scientific problems that limit the accuracy and scale range in current numerical representations of earthquake processes, which will benefit earthquake system science worldwide. This project will educate a diverse STEM workforce from the undergraduate to early-career level, and it will cross-train scientists and engineers in a challenging high-performance environment. As one application of SEISM, the project team will develop new simulations for the Great California ShakeOut, which is engaging millions of people in earthquake preparedness exercises.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Community Software for Extreme-Scale Computing in Earthquake System Science Project developed advanced earthquake simulation software capable of using high-performance computing (HPC) and produced new information about earthquakes and the hazards they present. Researchers from the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC) developed an integrated community software ecosystem (that includes Earth models, data structure, physics computational tools and workflows) to improve our understanding of fault rupture processes and seismic wave propagation through the Earth. This work highlights the important effects of sedimentary basins and ground motion directivity, as well as other 3D crustal structures on the seismic hazard, especially for long period motions that affect, for example, tall buildings. The cyberinfrastructure developed serves diverse communities of earthquake scientists, research engineers, computer scientists, and other stakeholders, such as utilities operators and emergency managers.

Intellectual Merit. The project extended the space and time scales of earthquake ground motion simulations by: (1) incorporating new physics into scientific codes to extend deterministic simulations to the high seismic frequencies of engineering interest (>1 Hz) into open-source community software; (2) working with a diverse community of researchers and stakeholders to validate simulation products for practical use; and (3) enhancing the performance and robustness of earthquake science computational platforms and preparing them to operate on next-generation supercomputers.

The SCEC open-source scientific software developed in this project provides improved earthquake rupture modeling and wave propagation and created an integrated software framework for advanced broadband estimation of ground motion hazard from earthquakes. These community codes were improved for performance and now incorporate models to account for material nonlinearity, frequency-dependent attenuation, topography and stochastic modifications of the subsurface structure (to represent material heterogeneities too fine to be resolved deterministically). We verified and validated the models by comparing simulation results to observed ground motions and applied the physics-based CyberShake probabilistic seismic hazard analysis (PSHA) framework to regions beyond southern California. The cyberinfrastructure developed is both a product and a tool that supports continued PSHA research.

Broader Impacts. Seismically active regions such as California are susceptible to large earthquakes. Adequate assessment of seismic hazard plays an essential role in seismic hazard mitigation (i.e. risk reduction) plans for a wide range of facilities, from houses and office buildings to critical facilities such as hospitals, dams, power plants as well as for utilities distribution systems. SCEC simulation software has led to impacts on  engineering design ground motions, urban planning activities, community earthquake awareness, and disaster preparation and response. SCEC simulation results and hazard estimation methods are under evaluation by (1) the United States Geological Survey (USGS) for use in the National Seismic Hazard Mapping Project, (2) the Building Seismic Safety Council and the American Society of Civil Engineers for the specification of tall building designs; and (3) the City of Los Angeles for inclusion in tall building design recommendations. CyberShake simulations have been used to train the USGS Earthquake Early Warning system recently deployed in California. Since 2008, our earthquake scenario simulations have been used to engage millions worldwide to participate in the Great ShakeOut earthquake preparedness drill each year.

Through this work we motivated and educated a diverse scientific workforce, from the undergraduate to early-career level, who can integrate system science with high-performance computing. In addition, computational geoscience has emerged as a research discipline related to, but distinct from either geoscience or computer science, and this project (along with others led by SCEC), is training a workforce in the multi-disciplinary skills needed to contribute to this new research discipline.
